Award.AbstractNarration:
PI name: John C. Crittenden
Institution: Arizona State University
Proposal Number: 0836046
EFRI-RESIN: Sustainable Infrastructures for Energy and Water Supply (SINEWS)

The goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive understanding of the sustainability and resilience of the water and energy systems, and to offer solutions that span infrastructure design, management of the physical environment, and socio-economic policy. SINEWS has four major research elements: (1) THE PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT. The project will model the growth of urban (built and natural) environment and the associated endogenous infrastructure risks. The technological, engineering, and ecological options for mitigating these risks over the life of the infrastructures will be identified. (2) THE INFRASTRUCTURES. The project will examine and model the resilience and sustainability of water and energy supply system options. Benchmarks will be identified for power and water supply systems that are resilient to the expected range of shocks, that are flexible, modular, adaptive, and efficient, and that reflect the interdependency of infrastructures and their environment. (3) THE SOCIO-ECONOMIC ENVIRONMENT. The project will model the infrastructure risks associated with the socio-economic environment - the demographic, economic, institutional and social drivers of water and energy demand, and identify risk management options under different socio-economic conditions. (4) LIFE CYCLE IMPLICATIONS of infrastructure options, e.g., decentralized versus centralized power and water systems. Overall, the proposed research represents a new systems approach to engineering the resilience and sustainability of critical infrastructures in the context of their physical and socio-economic environments. Simulations for integrated regional-scale models for Greater Phoenix will generate insights into the resilience and sustainability of water and energy infrastructures under a range of environmental scenarios. These insights are expected to contribute to a national research agenda for integrated urban sustainability science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to determine how to better engineer water and power infrastructures in the context of their physical and social-economic environment to assure efficiency (thereby enhancing sustainability), and to reduce the risk of supply or demand driven system failures (thereby increasing resilience)  through integrated planning, technological development and demand management. To achieve that goal SINEWS has developed: (a) A model architecture for evaluating the resilience of power and water infrastructures, (b) Design principles for both the infrastructures and the physical environment in which they are embedded, and (c) A set of decision-support tools for economic management of infrastructure risks over their lifespan.

The project involved multidisciplinary teams from Arizona State University, University of Georgia and Georgia Institute of Technology. The project evaluated alternative water and energy provision systems, their interdependence, lifecycle cost and environmental impacts, alternate land-use patterns and policy decisions increasing the sustainability and resilience of urban regions. It also developed new metrics to assess sustainability and resilience of integrated urban infrastructure systems. Among the alternative water and energy provision systems, this project evaluated the efficacy, life-cycle costs and environmental impacts of combined cooling, heat and power (CCHP) systems coupled with Solar PV systems, rainwater harvesting, graywater reclamation, and solid-oxide fuel cells. The analysis revealed that these decentralized alternatives are comparable with their centralized counterparts in cost and provide significant environmental benefit over the lifespan. The coupled CCHP-Solar PV systems show that it is feasible to develop a self-sufficient micro-grid based on exiting natural gas system that has potential to reduce the water for electricity generation by 60% (if using air-cooled microturbines).

For resilience the team evaluated resilience of water distribution networks (WDNs) with respect to mechanical failures through performance analysis of multiple resilience metrics. A genetic algorithm based multi-objective optimization was employed for WDN design that considers cost and Resilience. The results indicate long-term systems reliability demands larger diameter pipes resulting in higher cost and emissions. The team also evaluated the resilience of WDNs based on their topology using network analysis which revealed that topology can be altered to increase system resilience without any additional capital or O&M cost.

The team also evaluated the effects of socioeconomic drivers on adoption of more sustainable and resilient urban infrastructure. It developed an agent-based model (ABM) that evaluates the interactions between decision-makers and fiscal drivers to develop policy tools driving adoption. The ABM model predicts compact growth, more tax revenue and water savings in a more sustainable development scenario. To predict market potential for smart growth, a latent class choice model was developed which demonstrated incorporating stakeholder preferences into design doubles the adoption rate. The team also used changes in regional economic impact from substituting surface-water with groundwater. It revealed a change in water supplies depends critically on the price elasticity of water demand.

The SINEWS team also received two research supplement grants (1) to examine the role of visual-analytics of social media in resilient and sustainable urban infrastructure development, and (2) to catalyze new international collaboration. For the first supplemental grant, the team designed and implemented a fast, scalable and interactive algorithm for targeted topic discovery leveraging Twitter data to identify and understand people’s preference about resilient and sustainable urban infrastructure development. For the other supplemental grant, the team developed new collaborations with Research Center for Eco-environmental Sciences (RCEES) in China. A collaborative pilot project, a courtyard integrated ecological system (CIES) was developed in Baoting, Hainan. This CIES pattern reduced emergy consumption by 80% and CO2 footprint by 50% as compared to traditional pattern.

Intellectual Merit

By bringing together a trans-disciplinary team and fostering collaboration, the team developed a new paradigm for sustainable and resilient urban infrastructure development. The project addressed the sustainability of infrastructures in terms of life cycle impacts of energy and materials consumption together with a lifetime depreciation management strategy that will maintain the value of the public assets involved. In terms of resilience, the project focused on infrastructural design to enhance the flexibility and adaptability of the system in the face of exogenous and endogenous risks, and environmental design to mitigate endogenous risks. This project contributed to (a) developing a more integrated understanding of common principles of resilient and sustainable systems, and (b) identifying useful approaches and tools for enhancing the resilience, sustainability, and productive harmony of human and natural systems.

Broader Impacts

The developed integrated mathematical model(s) through this project include the knowledge from many other disciplines, such as civil engineering, policy making, economics, markets, mechanical engineering, sustainability, etc., which will benefit these disciplines and increase the interaction between these disciplines. The research results could provide guidance or technical references for the planning work done by network operators and engineers; inspire manufacturers of PV, microturbines, combined heat and power and fuel cells to improve efficiency and lower cost.
